posts.cooked:
We’re a shoestring budget team.

I read some posts about using ferrules on wires inserted into Weidmüller connectors that stated cheap ferrules don’t hold well and can break off in the blocks.  The suggestion was to either go bare wire (yuck) or shell out $350 for a genuine Weidmüller PZ6/5.

The main concern over these cheap ferrule crimpers seems to be the bumpy profile they leave behind which can lead to intermittent disconnects and pull outs.

I got to thinking that the Weidmüller contacts would probably hold fast if given a square profile smooth pin, so I tried crimping on a male mini- PV pin.

As far as I can tell, it seems to insert easily and hold fast.  The only problem is that you have to leave the housing off so the pin is long enough for insertion, and that exposes the contact body above the Weidmüller necessitating the addition of shrink tubing.

I can’t see any reason not to use this method… All the CAN devices are responding and the wiring is neat and appears to hold fast.  The pin is smooth and flat, and the Weidmüller seems to like that.

Any obvious objections to doing this or suggestions on an alternative cheap square profile pin that would work without having to omit the insulated housing?

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Unless you have a really good reason to not just use the free strands in weidmullers I wouldn’t risk anything, also it seems like a lot of work to the point where tinning the wires might be a better logistical option.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Do you have a picture of this setup?

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked:
I’m not familiar enough with mini- PV pins to comment on them, but we’ve often used ferrules on wires ranging from 24 AWG to 10 AWG, and we very seldom have electrical issues. You need a good crimper, but not a $300 crimper. For $26 this one is hard to beat:

image 1328×581 143 KB

image 1328×581 143 KB

image 1328×581 143 KB

Just make sure it’s a 4-jaw and not a 6-jaw crimper.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I have a generic one that looks exactly like this and all it does it makes weak ferrules that break apart easily. Is this specific brand better? I know some people recommend iCrimp.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: We’ve had no issues with the linked crimper, though we’ve had that specific tool only a year. Its predecessor looked just like it but got dropped on its head on concrete a few too many times.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
cwm9:

Weidmüller connectors that stated cheap ferrules don’t hold well and can break off in the blocks. The suggestion was to either go bare wire (yuck)

Weidmüller says “gimme that bare wire - yummy!”.  You may not think that’s tasty, but the connector manufacturer is fine with it.

Sounds like your testing is promising so you’re doing the right thing by checking it out.

Be careful about tinning as was suggested in another reply - many mfgrs expressly recc not to do that as it changes the characteristics of the wire enough to cause long term problems.  As an example, tinning for screw type terminals usually causes trouble, the solder starts to cold flow because of it’s softness and the tension on the connection is lost.

The connectors we’re talking about here have internal spring tension so that might be less of an issue but it’s still worth a look at the data sheet to see if they mention anything in that regard.

In the same way, some mfgrs will recommend not to twist a stranded wire and insert it as stripped for best contact and retention - I could see that by being able to flatten the wire for more contact area and better retention.  It feels “yucky” but it might just be the thing that works the best.

That connector was likely designed by someone that really knew what they were doing so I personally put a lot of weight on what they recommend.

Nothing wrong about being on a shoestring my friend - it might mean that sticking with the mfgr reccs is the best way to go if they actually end up not taking more time or more money - just sayin’…

posts.cooked:
It’s not that I don’t trust bare wire, it’s that we have to take our robot apart to ship it and the constant removal and reinsertion of the wire necessitates us shortening the wire repeatedly to get to undamaged strands.  Also it’s much slower to reassemble the robot that way.

Here’s what it looks like without shrink tubing:

17356032630968843042134150645238 1920×2550 139 KB

17356032630968843042134150645238 1920×2550 139 KB
